'''Programme One''' was a [[television]] channel produced and transmitted by [[Soviet Central Television]], the television broadcasting organization of the [[Soviet Union|USSR]]. It had a mixed schedule of news and entertainment, with the emphasis on events in the USSR, and also included regional programming.
==History== '''Programme One''' was established on 22 March 1951 when, as part of a reorganization of the television system, the '''Moscow Television Station''' changed its name to reflect its planned expansion. It was known officially as the ''' CT USSR Programme One''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: '''Первая программа ЦТ СССР''').
The channel, which was transmitted on the [[SECAM]] D/K standard, carried advertising for the first time in the 1980s. The channel was broadcast until 1991. In September of that year, it was renamed as '''Central Television Channel One''' (Russian: '''Первый канал ЦТ'''), and then in December, following the dissolution of the USSR, became '''Ostankino Television Channel One'''.
Following the [[dissolution of the USSR]], Programme One's frequencies were transferred to the new state broadcasting organizations in the former [[republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet republics]], while in the [[Russia]]n republic the main Ostankino Television channel took over its signal and transmitters.
==Programmes== The periodic [[Little Blue Light]] became a staple of [[Soviet Union]] celebrations during [[New Year's Eve]], [[International Women's Day]], and [[International Workers' Day]]. The programme continues to run today on [[Russia 1]].
The news department did not employ news journalists until 1989, when they began to front the shorter bulletins (the main 18:30 and 21:00 news programmes was fronted only by senior journasts until after the [[1991 Soviet coup d'etat attempt|failed coup d'etat]]).
==See also== *[[Eastern Bloc information dissemination]] *[[CCTV 1]] - similar channel in China {{Eastern Bloc media}}
[[Category:Eastern Bloc media]] [[Category:Soviet culture]] [[Category:Television in the Soviet Union]]

{{Infobox company | name = Rhizomatiks | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | former_name = | type = | industry = | founded = 2006, Tokyo | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | hq_location = | hq_location_city = Tokyo | hq_location_country = | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = Daito Manabe, Motoi Ishibashi, Seiichi Saito and Hidenori Chiba | products = | brands = | services = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | website = {{URL| rhizomatiks.com/}} }} '''Rhizomatiks''' is a Japanese company which is dedicated to creating large scale commercial and artistic projects using both the arts and technology. Founded in 2006, the company has members from various fields such as visuals arts, [[media arts]], computer programming, architecture, engineering and more. They have collaborated with various professionals and companies to produce music, dance recitals, videos and even sports such as a figure skate, facing, basketball and synchronised swimming. They came to wide attention in 2008 with Daito Manabe's YouTube video and 2010 with Perfume's live concert at Tokyo Dome and have become a common sight at [[Ars Electronica]] and [[transmedia]] festivals around the world.
==Origin== Rhizomatiks was founded as a collective of creative people in 2006 in Tokyo to work on large-scale commercial projects.<<ref name=dauerer>{{cite web |author= Verena Dauerer |title= <code+culture> part one |publisher= Japan Times |location=Tokyo |url= http://features.japantimes.co.jp/media-art-pt1/ |accessdate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref> One early project was with the Japanese pop group [[Perfume (Japanese band)|Perfume]], work with the single ''Polyrhythm'' in 2007, which led to touring with the band.<ref name=dauerer/><ref name=ftcom>{{cite news |author=Liz Jobey |title= Performance: Daito Manabe's light fantastic |newspaper=FT.com |date=July 26, 2013 }}</ref> They became widely noticed with a video piece in 2008 called ''Electric Stimulus To Face'', which had more than a million [[YouTube]] hits in its first month.<ref name=ftcom/>
The company has gone international, becoming a fixture at transmedia festivals around the world and has expanded its portfolio 10x.<ref name=dauerer/><ref name=ftcom/><ref name=fquiroz>{{cite news |author= Fernanda Quiroz |title= Lo más esperado en el Cervantino: Rhizomatiks + Elevenplay |newspaper= W Radio |location=Mexico City |url= http://www.wradio.com.mx/noticias/sociedad/8203lo-mas-esperado-en-el-cervantino-rhizomatiks--elevenplay/20141009/nota/2454462.aspx |accessdate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref>
In 2014, the collaborated with dance troup [[Elevenplay]], appearing at the [[Festival Internacional Cervantino]].<ref name=fquiroz/><ref name=fusionan>{{cite news |title= Artistas japoneses fusionan el arte y la tecnología |newspaper=El Universal |location= Mexico City |date=October 9, 2014 }}</ref> They also participated in the [[Art Fair Tokyo]] 2015, by displaying their "mega-synth system," which works like a regular [[synthesizer]].<ref name=timeout>{{cite web |author= Maru Cube |title= RBMA x Rhizomatiks: The Human Sized Synthesizer |publisher= Time Out |location=Tokyo |date= March 22, 2015 |url= http://www.timeout.jp/en/tokyo/event/13650/RBMA-x-Rhizomatiks-The-Human-Sized-Synthesizer |accessdate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref>
==Members== Rhizomatiks is an eclectic combination of creators which includes architects, visual artists, media artists, designers, musicians, engineers and programmers.
The founder of the group is {{Interlanguage link multi|Daito Manabe|ko|3=다이토 마나베}} (1976), an artist, composer, programmer, designer, DJ and [[VJing|VJ]].<ref name=fquiroz/><ref name=fusionan/><ref name=todaysart>{{cite web |title= Daito Manabe – Rhizomatiks |publisher= Today's Art |location=Netherlands |date= 2014 |url= http://todaysart.nl/2014/summit/daito-manabe/ |accessdate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref> Manabe is from a traditional media art environment, with a degree in dynamic sensory programming from the [[International Academy of Media Arts and Sciences]] and a degree in mathematics from the T[[okyo University of Science]].<ref name=dauerer/><ref name=todaysart/>
The CTO of the group is Motoi Ishibashi (1976), an artist and engineer. Lives and works in Tokyo. Ishibashi studied control systems engineering at the Tokyo Institute of Technology, followed by mechanical and image processing engineering at the Institute of Advanced Media Arts and Sciences (IAMAS) in Gifu, at the inception of digital media production. He met Manabe at IAMAS, who was also a student there. He is currently working on the development of new artistic methods touching on both the visual environment and the elaboration of engineering solutions in terms of artistic production and interactive public spaces. In 2011, he and Manabe were the recipients of an Award of Distinction in the interactive art category of the Prix Ars Electronica. That same year, he received the Excellence Award at the 15th edition of the Japan Media Art Festival. Since 2015, he has co-directed Rhizomatiks Research along with Manabe, a strand devoted to research and development in the spheres of art, technology and entertainment.<ref name=dauerer/><ref name=members>{{cite web |title= Members |publisher= Rhizomatiks|location=Tokyo |url= http://rhizomatiks.com/#/members/ |accessdate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref>
Founding member Seiichi Saito (1975) studied architectural design At [[Columbia University]] in New York and worked in advertising starting in 2000 before returning to Japan and joining Rhizomatiks.<ref name=dauerer/><ref name=jinsmeme>{{cite web |title= EPISODE 01 SEIICHI SAITO/RHIZOMATIKS × KENTARO SHIHAKU/GLIDER |publisher= Jins Meme |location=Japan |url= https://www.jins-jp.com/jinsmeme/en/episode/episode01.html |accessdate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref> His is noted for this three-dimensional interactive commercial art work, based on architectural concepts. Today he is the director of the company and also lectures part-time at the Tokyo University of Science.<ref name=jinsmeme/>
Other founding member is Hidenori Chiba, who has a background in website development. Currently his is in charge of web design, system engineering and programming.<ref name=dauerer/><ref name="members" />
Other members of the company include Satoshi Horii, Daisuke Nakahama, Hiroyuki Hori, Hiroyasu Kimora, Sumito Kamoi, Ichiro Kojima, Youichi Sakamoto, Muryo Honma, Motoi Ishibashi, Megumi Shima and Keisuki Arikuni.<ref name=members/>
==Work and artistry== Rhizomatiks produces interactive materials with their work crossing the boundaries between design, art and entertainment.<ref name=fquiroz/> Projects often involved collecting massive amounts of data using [[motion capture]], [[kinect controller]]<nowiki/>s and sensors to track dance movements in order to recreate human forms and movements as 3-D representations in real time. They also use [[projection mapping]], lasers, sonar, robots and even drones.<ref name=dauerer/><ref name=ftcom/><ref name=conaculta>{{cite web |title= Rhizomatiks x elevenplay Pulse |publisher= CONACULTA |location=Mexico |url= http://www.conaculta.gob.mx/estados/actividades_detalle.php?id=116827#.VTZZwPBZ1rk |accessdate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref>
New ideas will cross between artistic and commercial projects. The commercial pieces tend to be on a larger scale because of funding.<ref name=dauerer/> ''(Rhizomatiks) is like a music label'', Manabe says. ''People with similar values gather and each person pursues different projects''.<ref name=dauerer/> Leadership changes from project to project. ''They’re a challenging group of people'', Shimizu says. ''Whether the project's commercial or noncommercial in nature, they aren’t able to stop trying something new. They are not just artists, they’re also Japanese craftsmen who focus on detail. This might also explain why they are essentially ‘process driven’ (in the way they approach projects).''<ref name=dauerer/>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Design companies]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of Japan]] [[Category:Media companies of Japan]] [[Category:Design companies established in 2006]] [[Category:2006 establishments in Japan]]

{{Orphan|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = Ster Cinemas | logo = | type = [[Subsidiary]] | num_employees = 500 (2014) | foundation = 2004 | parent = '''Audio Visual Enterprises S.A.''' | net_income = {{increase}}[[Euro|€]]10.6 million (2015) | industry = [[Movie theater|Cinema]] [[entertainment]] | key_people = [[Vardinogiannis|Amalia Vardinoyannis]] ([[CEO]]) | location = [[Athens, Greece]] | products = [[Movie theater|Cinemas]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.stercinemas.gr/}} }} '''Ster Cinemas''' S.A. is a Greek chain of cinemas. It has sites across Greece.
==The company== Ster Cinemas is a Greek company, a subsidiary of '''Audio Visual Enterprises S.A.''' ([[Vardinogiannis]] group of companies). The Ster Cinemas group operates near large Greek urban centres (Athens, Thessaloniki, Patras, Larissa and Chania).
==Sites== Cinemas operated under the Ster Cinemas brand include:
===Greece=== * Ster Ilion in Ilion [[Athens]] 8 screens & 1 Summer (1 3D) * Ster Macedonia in [[Thessaloniki]] 11 screens (2 3D) * Ster Pantheon Plaza in [[Larissa]] 3 screens (1 3D) * Ster Veso Mare in [[Patras]] 8 screens (2 3D) * Ster Mega Place in [[Chania]],Greece 3 screens (1 3D)
Ster Cinemas also operated the following sites, until they were sold to [[Cineplexx Cinemas|Cineplexx International]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cineplexx expands in former Yugoslavia|url=http://www.screendaily.com/cineplexx-expands-in-former-yugoslavia/5032266.article|accessdate=4 April 2015}}</ref>
===Montenegro=== * Ster Montenegro, 5 screens(closed, now Cineplexx)
===Serbia=== * Ster Cinemas Beograd, 7 screens

[[File:Teleview 1922.jpg|thumb|300px|An illustration from a 1922 article about Teleview]] [[File:Teleview viewer.jpg|thumb|300px|Details of the Teleview viewer]] '''Teleview''' was a system for projecting [[3D film|stereoscopic motion pictures]] invented by [[Laurens Hammond]],<ref>U.S. Patents 1,435,520, 1,506,524 and 1,658,439</ref> best known as the inventor of the [[Hammond organ]]. It made its public debut on 27 December 1922 at the [[Selwyn Theatre]] in [[New York City]], the only theater ever equipped with the system. The program included several short films, a live presentation of projected 3D shadows, and the 95-minute feature film ''M.A.R.S.'' (or ''[[The Man from M.A.R.S. (1922 film)|The Man From M.A.R.S.]]''), later re-released in 2D as ''Radio-Mania''.
Teleview pioneered the [[alternate-frame sequencing]] method of stereoscopic 3D projection. The basic principle had been patented as early as 1897, but the improved Teleview implementation was the first to be presented to the public.
Left-eye and right-eye films were run through a pair of interlocked projectors with their shutters operating out of phase. Each shutter was three-bladed, so that each pair of film frames was projected three times (i.e., left-right-left-right-left-right) before the mechanisms moved the next pair of frames into position. At the minimum 16-frames-per-second silent film projection speed, this resulted in a minimum of 48 flashes per second per eye, eliminating the severe flicker that fatally flawed earlier systems in which the left-eye and right-eye frames alternated on a single strip of film projected at twice the normal rate.
Each theater seat was equipped with an attached viewing device supported by a gooseneck stand. It contained a rotary shutter synchronized with the projector shutters, so that each of the user's eyes saw only the images intended for it. [[Persistence of vision]] made both views appear to be uninterrupted and a normal fully stereoscopic image was seen.
Hammond's system won praise, but because of the high cost of installing the equipment, and the inconvenience of having to peer through the unwieldy viewer, it disappeared completely after this lone engagement ended in early 1923.<ref>Zone, Ray (2007). ''Stereoscopic Cinema and the Origins of 3-D Film, 1838-1952'', University Press of Kentucky, pp. 107-109.</ref>
The alternating image method enjoyed a revival after the advent of [[optoelectronics|optoelectronic]] shutters in the 1970s made it more practical. Modern [[LC shutter glasses]] are used for viewing projected 3D films in some theaters, as well as [[3DTV]] video and stereoscopic computer graphics.
==See also== *[[List of 3D films]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110707063258/http://www.3dmovingpictures.com/chopper.html "The Chopper," article about Teleview by Daniel L. Symmes] *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0014391 ''Radio-Mania'' at IMDB ] *[http://www.didik.com/3d_film.htm Directory of 3D (Stereo) Motion Pictures 1922–2001] *[https://www.nature.com/scientificamerican/journal/v128/n1/pdf/1923-01-01.pdf Scientific American, Vol 128, n1, page 5, january 1923 ]
[[Category:3D cinema]] [[Category:Motion picture film formats]]

{{Infobox software | name = Tux Paint | logo = Tux paint logo.png | logo size = 100px | screenshot = Tux Paint.png | screenshot size = 250px | caption = A screenshot of a blank drawing canvas on Tux Paint in English. | developer = Bill Kendrick, et al. | released = {{Start date and age|2002|06|16}} | latest_release_version = 0.9.23 | latest_release_date = {{Start date and age|2018|9|1}}<ref>{{cite mailing list|url=https://sourceforge.net/p/tuxpaint/mailman/message/36405651/|title=Tux Paint 0.9.23, Config 0.0.14, Stamps 2018-09-01 tarballs posted!|mailing-list=tuxpaint-devel|last1=Kendrick|first1=Bill|date=1 September 2018|accessdate=2 September 2018|via=[[SourceForge]]}}</ref> | operating_system = [[Cross-platform]] | programming language = [[C (programming language)|C]] | genre = [[Raster graphics editor]] | license = [[GNU General Public License]] | website = {{URL|www.tuxpaint.org}} }}
'''''Tux Paint''''' is a [[raster graphics editor]] (a program for creating and processing [[raster graphics]]) geared towards young children. The project was started in 2002 by Bill Kendrick who continues to maintain and improve it, with help from numerous volunteers. Tux Paint is seen by many as a free software alternative to [[Kid Pix]], a similar [[proprietary software|proprietary]] [[educational software]] product.<ref>[http://www.macmerc.com/news/newsbite/893 MacMerc review of Tux Paint], June 18, 2003.</ref>
== History ==
Tux Paint was initially created for the [[Linux]] operating system, as there was no suitable drawing program for young children available for Linux at that time.<ref>[http://www.osnews.com/story.php/1549/Interview-with-Bill-Kendrick-of-NewBreedSoftware/ Interview with Bill Kendrick of NewBreedSoftware at OSNews], August 16, 2002.</ref> It is written in the [[C (programming language)|C programming language]] and uses various free and open source [[library (software)|helper libraries]], including [[Simple DirectMedia Layer|the Simple DirectMedia Layer (SDL)]], and has since been made available for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X|Apple Mac OS X]], [[BeOS]] and other platforms.
Selected milestone releases:
* 2002.06.16 (June 16, 2002) - Initial release (brushes, stamps, lines, eraser), two days after coding started * 2002.06.30 (June 30, 2002) - First Magic tools added (blur, blocks, negative) * 2002.07.31 (July 31, 2002) - Localization support added * 0.9.11 (June 17, 2003) - Right-to-left support, UTF-8 support in Text tool * 0.9.14 (October 12, 2004) - '''Tux Paint Config.''' configuration tool released, Starter image support * 0.9.16 (October 21, 2006) - Slideshow feature, animated and directional brushes * 0.9.17 (July 1, 2007) - Arbitrary screen size and orientation support, [[SVG]] support, [[input method]] support * 0.9.18 (November 21, 2007) - Magic Tools turned into plug-ins, [[Pango]] text rendering
== Features == [[File:Tuxpaint-drawing.png|thumb|Drawing with Tux Paint's Paint tool]]
Tux Paint stands apart from typical graphics editing software (such as [[GIMP]] or [[Photoshop]]) that it was designed to be usable by [[children]] as young as 3 years of age. The [[user interface]] is meant to be intuitive, and utilizes [[icon (computing)|icons]], audible feedback and textual hints to help explain how the software works. The brightly colored interface, [[sound effects]] and cartoon mascot ([[Tux (mascot)|Tux]], the mascot of the Linux kernel) are meant to engage children.
Tux Paint's normal interface is split into five sections:
* Toolbox, containing the various basic tools (see below) and application controls ([[undo]], save, new, [[printing|print]]) * Canvas, where the [[digital image|images]] are drawn and edited * Color [[Palette (computing)|palette]], where colors can be chosen (when applicable to the current tool) * Selector, providing various selectable objects (e.g., brushes, [[digital font|fonts]] or sub-tools, depending on the current tool) * Information area, where instructions, tips and encouragement are provided
A simple [[slideshow]] feature allows previously saved images to be displayed as a basic flip-book [[animation]] or as a slide [[presentation]].
=== Basic drawing tools ===
Like most popular graphics editing and composition tools, Tux Paint includes a paintbrush, an eraser, and tools to draw lines, [[polygon|polygonal shapes]] and text. Tux Paint provides multiple levels of [[undo]] and [[redo]], allowing accidental or unwanted changes to be removed while editing a picture.
=== Files and printing ===
Tux Paint was designed in such a way that the user does not need to understand the underlying [[operating system]] or how to [[Computer file management|deal with files]]. The "Save" and "Open" commands were designed to mimic those of software for [[personal digital assistant]] devices, such as the [[Palm Pilot|Palm]] handheld.<ref>[http://www.tuxpaint.org/reviews/communitykids/ "Tux Paint Great Fun for Your Kids... If They Can Get You Off the Program!"], Community Kids Magazine, December 2007</ref> When one saves a picture in Tux Paint, they do not need to provide a [[computer file|file]] name or [[file browser|browse]] for where to place it. When one goes to open a previously saved picture, a collection of [[thumbnail]]s of saved images is shown.
Similarly, printing is typically a 'no questions asked' process, as well.
=== Advanced drawing tools === [[File:Tuxpaint-magic-tools.png|thumb|A drawing made with a variety of Magic Tools]]
Tux Paint includes a number of 'filters' and 'special effects' which can be applied to a drawing, such as [[Gaussian blur|blurring]], fading, and making the picture look as though it was drawn in [[chalk]] on [[pavement (roads)|pavement]]. These are available through the 'Magic' tool in Tux Paint. Starting with version 0.9.18, Tux Paint's 'Magic' tools are built as [[Plug-in (computing)|plugins]] that are loaded at runtime and use a [[C (programming language)|C]] [[Application programming interface|API]] specifically for creating such tools.<ref>[http://www.tuxpaint.org/latest/tuxpaint-0.9.18-press-release-en.php3 Tux Paint 0.9.18 press release], November 21, 2007.</ref>
[[File:Tuxpaint-space-stamps.png|thumb|left|A space scene using Tux Paint Rubber Stamps]]
A large collection of [[art]]work and [[Photography|photographic]] imagery are also available (under a [[license]] allowing free redistribution), and may be placed inside drawings using Tux Paint's "[[Rubber stamp|Rubber Stamp]]" tool. Stamps can be in either [[Raster graphics|raster (bitmap)]] format (in [[Portable Network Graphics|PNG]] format, supporting 24[[color depth|bpp]] and full [[alpha channel|alpha]] transparency), or as [[vector graphics]] (in [[Scalable Vector Graphics|SVG]] format) on many platforms Tux Paint supports. As of mid-2008, over 800 stamps are included in the stamps collection.
=== Parental and teacher controls === [[File:Tuxpaint-config-sshot.png|thumb|Tux Paint Config., a graphical configuration tool for Tux Paint]]
As features are added to Tux Paint, [[computer configuration|configuration]] options have been added that allow parents and teachers to disable features and alter the behavior to better suit their children's or students' needs, or to better integrate the software in their home or school computing environment. Typical options, such as enabling or disabling sound effects and full-screen mode are available. There are also options that help make Tux Paint suitable for younger or [[disabled]] children, such as displaying text using only [[uppercase]] letters or ignoring the distinction between buttons on the [[Computer mouse|mouse]].
=== Localization ===
Tux Paint has been [[translation|translated]] into numerous languages, and has support for the display of text in languages that use non-Latin character sets, such as [[Japanese language|Japanese]], [[Greek language|Greek]], or [[Telugu language|Telugu]]. As of June 2008, over 80 languages are supported.<ref>[http://www.tuxpaint.org/help/po/ "Help Us Translate"] page at Tux Paint website</ref> Correct support for complex languages requires [[Pango]]. [[Sound effects]] and descriptive sounds for stamp imagery can also be localized. Tux Paint includes its own form of [[input method]] support, allowing entry of non-Latin characters using the 'Text' tool.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuxpaint.org/latest/tuxpaint-0.9.17-press-release-en.php3 |title=Tux Paint 0.9.17 announcement |publisher=Tuxpaint.org |date=2007-07-01 |accessdate=2013-11-11}}</ref> Japanese ([[Romanized]] [[Hiragana]] and Romanized [[Katakana]]), Korean ([[Hangul|Hangul 2-bul]]) and Traditional Chinese are currently supported.
== Distribution == [[File:tuxpaint-golden-gate-bridge-sf.png|thumb|"[[Golden Gate Bridge]]", drawn using Tux Paint]]
Tux Paint is included with the software that comes with the [[ASUS Eee PC]]. It is also a standard package in educationally oriented [[Linux distribution]]s, such as [[Debian]] Jr. and [[Edubuntu]], as an optional package in numerous other Linux distributions, as well as part of numerous educationally oriented Linux [[Live CD]]s. It is included in various software collections for Windows (such as [[GNUWin II]] and [[Open Source Software CD]]), as well as in [[Portable application|portable software]] collections for Windows, since it can be run as a stand-alone application (without needing to be installed system-wide). Tux Paint is also available as an activity within the free and open source educational suite [[GCompris]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tuxpaint.org/links/#distributors |title=Tux Paint distributors |publisher=Tuxpaint.org |date= |accessdate=2013-11-11}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Free software}}
* [[GCompris]] * [[List of raster graphics editors]] * [[Comparison of raster graphics editors]] * [[Tux Typing]] * [[Tux, of Math Command]] * [[MyPaint]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{commons category}}
* {{Official website|http://www.tuxpaint.org/ }} * {{sourceforge|tuxpaint|Tux Paint}} * [http://www.tux4kids.com/ Tux4Kids]
{{Raster graphics editors}} {{GTK}}
[[Category:Free raster graphics editors]] [[Category:Free software programmed in C]] [[Category:Software for children]] [[Category:Raster graphics editors for Linux|Tux paint]] [[Category:Cross-platform software]] [[Category:Open-source educational video games]] [[Category:Portable software]] [[Category:Free educational software]] [[Category:GNOME Kids]] [[Category:Free and open-source Android software]] [[Category:Raster graphics editors]]

{{Italic title}} The '''''Warsaw Concerto''''' is a short work for piano and orchestra by [[Richard Addinsell]], written for the 1941 British film ''[[Dangerous Moonlight]]'', which is about the Polish struggle against the 1939 invasion by [[Polish areas annexed by Nazi Germany|Nazi Germany]]. In performance it normally lasts just under ten minutes. The concerto is an example of [[programme music]], representing both the struggle for Warsaw and the romance of the leading characters in the film. It became very popular in Britain during [[World War II]]. The concerto is written in imitation of the style of [[Sergei Rachmaninoff]]. It initiated a trend for similar short piano concertos in the Romantic style, which have been dubbed "tabloid concertos". ==Background== The composer, [[Richard Addinsell]], was born in London and initially studied law before turning to a career in music. His time at the Royal College of Music was brief, as he was soon drawn to musical theatre, and he also wrote for radio, but his most memorable contributions are to a series of film scores beginning in 1936. He wrote the music for the 1939 film ''[[Goodbye, Mr. Chips (1939 film)|Goodbye, Mr. Chips]]'', the original ''[[Gaslight (1940 film)|Gaslight]]'' (released in 1940, not to be confused with the later Hollywood version), ''[[Scrooge (1951 film)|Scrooge]]'', and ''Dangerous Moonlight'' (1941, also released in the US as ''Suicide Squadron''). It is this last picture that began the trend of “tabloid concertos,”K. J. Donnelly, ''British Film Music and Film Musicals'' (Basingstoke: Palgrave Macmillan, 2007), 50. John Huntley defines the term as a "piece of context film music which was duly recorded and edited into the finished film". See his ''British Film Music'' (New York: Arno Press & The New York Times, 1972), 54. classical-style compositions written for performance in movies. John Huntley explores the reason behind this concept:
The associations which individual members of the audience may have in relation to a certain piece of well-known music are quite beyond the control of the director of a film in which it is used…. And so with ''Dangerous Moonlight'' it was rightly decided to have a piece of music specially written, that could be used to become associated in the mind of the audience with Poland, air raids in Warsaw, and whatever the director wanted to suggest.John Huntley, ''British Film Music'' (New York: Arno Press & The New York Times, 1972), 53–54.
The concerto was not part of the original plan. According to [[Roy Douglas]], at that time orchestrator for all of Addinsell's scores: "The film's director had originally wanted to use [[Sergei Rachmaninoff]]'s [[Piano Concerto No. 2 (Rachmaninoff)|Second Piano Concerto]], but this idea was either forbidden by the copyright owners or was far too expensive".Roy Douglas, "The Warsaw Connection: Roy Douglas Remembers How It Actually Turned Out", ''ICRC'' 18 (1999): 62; reprinted with slight changes in Jan G. Swynnoe, ''The Best Years of British Film Music: 1936–1958'' (Woodbridge: Boydell Press, 2002), 215. Thus Addinsell wanted the piece to sound as much like Rachmaninoff as possible, and Douglas remembers, "while I was orchestrating the ''Warsaw Concerto'' I had around me the miniature scores of the Second and [[Piano Concerto No. 3 (Rachmaninoff)|Third]] Piano Concertos, as well as the ''[[Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini]]''." And although it is at the heart of ''Dangerous Moonlight'', the Concerto is never performed complete but rather revealed piecemeal. The opening of the work is heard when the two protagonists meet, and it is further developed when they are on their honeymoon. Finally, in the only extended concert sequence, we are given the closing section. But its use is not restricted to scenes with the "composer" at the piano. The themes are found as underscoring throughout the film, and in this way a brief concert piece gains a dramatic resonance that belies its small scale. ==Role in the film== ''Dangerous Moonlight'' takes place at the start of World War II and tells the story of a Polish concert pianist and composer, Stefan Radecki ([[Anton Walbrook]]) who defends his country by becoming a fighter pilot. After an air raid in Warsaw by the German army, he is discovered by an American reporter, Carol Peters ([[Sally Gray]]), practising the piano in a bombed-out building. It is the opening of his ''Warsaw Concerto'', at this point a work in progress, and the first line he says to her is, "It is not safe to be out alone when the moon is so bright" (referring to the moonlight bombing raids). Gazing intently at Carol and disclosing "something lovely you've just given me", he introduces the lyrical second theme of the Concerto. And, indeed, this melody is always associated with Carol.Laing, Heather, "The Gendered Score: Music and Gender in 1940s Melodrama and the Woman's Film", Ashgate Publishing, 2007, pp.156-9. Like Rachmaninoff, Addinsell introduces it almost as a nocturne. Stefan speaks of the piece later in the film: "This music is you and me. It's the story of the two of us in Warsaw, of us in America, of us in … where else I don't know. That's why I can't finish it". But finish it he does. Similar to the way that Rachmaninoff returns to his second theme in his Second Piano Concerto, the "Carol" melody is used, not only to bind together the emotional strands of the drama, but to bring the Concerto to a triumphant conclusion. Throughout the film, the unfinished piece is defined in a relationship with [[Frédéric Chopin]]'s [[Polonaises Op. 40 (Chopin)|"Military" Polonaise]], symbolising Polish patriotism. It is "completed" when the Polonaise elements are integrated with the Romantic theme, implying the fusion of romantic and patriotic love. Within the context of its story, ''Dangerous Moonlight'' is also effective in creating the impression of a larger work written and performed by the film's fictional composer and pianist. When snatches of the Concerto are first played, one character tells another, "I've got the records", and when the "premiere" is shown, we are provided with a close-up of the program, ''Warsaw Concerto'', with three movements listed. Only one movement was actually written by Addinsell. ==Popularity== The success of the film led to an immediate demand for the work, and a recording was dutifully supplied from the film’s soundtrack (at nine minutes, it fit perfectly on two sides of a 12-inch disk playing at 78 rpm) along with sheet music for a piano solo version.Huntley, ''British Film Music,'' 54. Such unexpected success had another consequence. The off-screen piano part was played by [[Louis Kentner]], a fine British musician known for his performances of [[Franz Liszt]], but he had insisted that there be no on-screen credit, for fear that his participation in a popular entertainment would harm his classical reputation.Douglas, ''The Warsaw Connection'', 62. He lost his qualms when the recording sold in the millions, and Douglas notes that he even asked for royalties (they were granted).In the revised version of Douglas's article that appeared in Swynnoe, ''The Best Years of British Film Music,'' Douglas learned that Kentner did not receive royalties; see p. 216. Ultimately the ''Warsaw Concerto'' was such a hit that it made the then unusual journey from movie screen to concert hall. In his 1944 appearance on ''[[Desert Island Discs]]'', [[Guy Gibson]], leader of the [[No. 617 Squadron RAF|Dambusters]] raid, asked for it as his first choice.Morris, Richard (1994). ''Guy Gibson''. London: Viking, Penguin Group. pp. 233–234. One commentator has suggested that the ''Warsaw Concerto'' is the most significant instrumental work written in Britain during the war, still conjuring up a time and place better than any other piece.Lane, Philip (2003). Liner notes to CD ''The Film Music of Richard Addinsell''. ==Arrangements, adaptations, quotes and samples== *[[Percy Grainger]] transcribed and recomposed the work for two pianos in the 1940s. *[[Don "Creesh" Hornsby]] included a version of the ''Concerto'' in his comedy act, often performed suspended by his heels, in the late 1940s. *The [[Theme (music)|theme]] of the ''Concerto'' is borrowed in a [[popular music|popular-music]] [[love song]] whose lyrics include "The world outside will never know..." recorded by [[The Four Coins]] in 1958.{{cite web|url=http://www.ntl.matrix.com.br/pfilho/html/lyrics/w/world_outside.txt |format=TXT|title="The World Outside" lyrics|website=Ntl.matrix.xom.br|accessdate=2016-07-28}} The ''Concerto'' theme charted at #18 on UK Singles chart in January 1959, as "The World Outside" by [[Ronnie Hilton]], a very popular singer in the UK. It was also recorded by [[The Four Aces]] *Pianist [[Liberace]] featured the ''Warsaw Concerto'' regularly on stage and on his 1952 album, "Liberace, Super Hits" *In 1999 US Rapper [[DMX (rapper)|DMX]] sampled the ''Concerto'' on the single "[[What's My Name? (DMX song)|What's my name]]", which was the first release from his US nº 1 album ''[[...And Then There Was X]]'' * [[George Greeley]] recorded the ''Concerto'' on both his 1957 Warner Bros. album ''The World's Ten Greatest Popular Piano Concertos'', and his 1963 album ''A Classic Affair.'' *[[José Carreras]] recorded the ''Concerto'' as the opening track on his 1999 album ''Pure Passion'' *[[Gonzalo Rubalcaba]], the [[Grammy Award]]-winning [[Cuba]]n jazz pianist and composer, recorded a Latin arrangement of the ''Warsaw Concerto'' in 2005 *A live version of the ''Concerto'', featuring [[Richard Carpenter (musician)|Richard Carpenter]] on the piano, was included on [[the Carpenters]]' album [[Live at the Palladium (The Carpenters album)|Live at the Palladium]], clocking in at 6'35''. *[[Richard Clayderman]] recorded an arrangement for the piece with the [[Royal Philharmonic Orchestra]] for his album ''The Classic Touch'', which was released in 1985 *The music was used in the film, ''[[The Sea Wolves]]'' (1980), with Addinsell's themes arranged by [[Roy Budd]]. *New Orleans R&B pianist [[James Booker]] recorded the opening section of the work. It appears on the "Expanded Edition" of Booker's album "Classified", issued by [[Rounder Records]] in 2013. * The [[Theme (music)|theme]] of the ''Concerto'' is the principal theme of the radio program [["La música de los clásicos]] (The Music of the Classics), produced by the dominican tenor [[Arístides Incháustegui]], in the radio transmitter "Raíces" in The Dominican Republic. ==Other pop culture references== *British composer Clive Richardson composed [[London Fantasia]] as a sequel to the Warsaw Concerto in 1944.{{cite web|author=Clive Richardson |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/clive-richardson-mn0001573769/biography |title=Clive Richardson | Biography & History |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |date= |accessdate=2016-07-28}} The work had gained success during that time and appeared in both Piano-Orchestra and Piano solo version with the word description 'A musical picture of The Battle of Britain'. *[[Spike Milligan]] repeatedly refers to the piece in his autobiography ''[[Adolf Hitler: My Part in His Downfall]]'' (1971) and in the subsequent books in the series as 'the bloody awful Warsaw Concerto'. *The ''Concerto'' is frequently used in championship figure skating (especially in Japan). *The composer and presenter [[Steve Race]] coined the term ''Denham Concerto'' for such short romantic film pieces as the Warsaw Concerto, [[Hubert Bath]]'s ''Cornish Rhapsody'' and [[Charles Williams (composer)|Charles Williams]]' ''The Dream of Olwen'', after the [[Denham Film Studios]].{{cite web|url=http://www.classicalsource.com/db_control/db_concert_review.php?id=5100 |title=British Light Classics @www.classicalsource.com |website=Classicalsource.com |date=2007-10-30 |accessdate=2016-07-28}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://classyclassical.blogspot.com/2005/10/richard-addinsells-warsaw-concerto.html Richard Addinsell's Warsaw Concerto] Analysis and description of Addinsell's Warsaw Concerto * [http://content.library.ccsu.edu/cdm/ref/collection/ccsutheses/id/2072 The Warsaw Concerto: Analysis, Influence, and Influences] In-depth analysis of the Warsaw Concerto, its use in ''Dangerous Moonlight'', the music that influenced it, and the music it influenced * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio3/cotw/pip/we8cu/ Composers of the Week] - Addinsell and Noël Coward * {{IMDb title|id=0033511|title=Dangerous Moonlight}} [[Category:Compositions by Richard Addinsell]] [[Category:Piano concertos]] [[Category:Film music]] [[Category:Film soundtracks]] [[Category:1941 compositions]]

revision.comment: +{{[[Template:Authority control|Authority control]]}} (7 sources from Wikidata), [[WP:GenFixes]] on, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Władysław Machejek | image = Władysław Machejek.jpg | image_size = | alt = Władysław Machejek | caption = Machejek at his party office, 1967 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1920|02|25}} | birth_place = Chodów, Poland | death_date = {{Death date and age|1991|12|21|1920|02|25}} | death_place = Kraków, Poland | citizenship = [[Poles|Polish]] | other_names = | known_for = [[Polish United Workers Party]] deputy | occupation = Party official, aspiring writer }} '''Władysław Machejek''' (February 25, 1920 – December 21, 1991) was a [[communist]] [[apparatchik|official]], an aspiring writer and [[Hoax|hoax artist]] during the [[Ministry of Public Security (Poland)#The Stalinist reign of terror|Stalinist reign of terror]] in [[Poland]] following World War II. He wrote fabricated accounts of [[Cursed soldiers|anti-communist underground]] mainly for his own political gains as regional [[party secretary]] and later member of the communist highest parliamentary echelons.<ref name="niniwa2">{{cite web | url=http://niniwa2.cba.pl/towarzysze_nieudanej_podrozy_14.htm | title=Co ja robię w tym kościele | publisher=''[[Gazeta Wyborcza]]'' | work=Towarzysze Nieudanej Podrózy | date=June 3, 2000 | accessdate=August 25, 2012 | author=Anna Bikont, Joanna Szczęsna }}</ref> Due to the coarse and infamous nature of his works, he has been described as a "legendary socialist scribbler".<ref>{{cite web|author=Janusz Anderman |url=http://wiadomosci.gazeta.pl/kraj/1,34311,138634.html |title=Machejek, Władysław (1920-1991) |publisher=Wiadomosci.gazeta.pl |date= |accessdate=2012-08-27}}</ref>
==Biography== Machejek was born on February 25, 1920 into a peasant family in the hamlet of [[Chodów, Lesser Poland Voivodeship|Chodów]]. He joined the [[Communist Party of Poland]] as a youth.<ref name=osaarchivum>{{cite web|url=http://www.osaarchivum.org/files/holdings/300/8/3/text/116-1-259.shtml |title=A Rumanian-Polish Literary Controversy |publisher=Osaarchivum.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-27}}</ref> During World War II he served in the Soviet-sponsored partisan organizations [[Gwardia Ludowa]] and [[Armia Ludowa]].<ref name=onet>{{cite web|url=http://portalwiedzy.onet.pl/36217,,,,machejek_wladyslaw,haslo.html |title=Machejek Władysław - WIEM, darmowa encyklopedia |publisher=Portalwiedzy.onet.pl |date= |accessdate=2012-08-27}}</ref> After the war he became a member of the new Polish communist party [[PZPR]] and took over the post of its regional secretary in the town of [[Nowy Targ]] not far from where he grew up. Soon, he became a member of the provincial party cell in [[Kraków]], and eventually deputy to the [[Sejm]] (Polish parliament) in the [[People's Republic of Poland]].<ref name=osaarchivum/><ref name=onet/> He was selected editor-in-chief of ''[[Życie Literackie]]'' magazine under Stalinism (1952) and became a prolific writer of ideological propaganda and coarse, often embarrassing polemics supporting the communist [[Party line (politics)|party line]].<ref name=onet/><ref name="Paczkowski"/><ref name="Drozdowski1998">{{cite book|author=Marian Marek Drozdowski|title=1956: polska emigracja a Kraj : antologia żródeł|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZAYrAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=27 August 2012|year=1998|publisher=Oficyna Wydawnicza "Typografika"|isbn=978-83-86417-31-5|page=109}}</ref> He has also been known on occasion to attack the authorities of other communist countries (such as [[Romania]]), but his criticism was tolerated.<ref name=osaarchivum/> It is said he always carried a bottle of vodka in his hollow briefcase.<ref name="niniwa2" /> Machejek died in [[Kraków]] at the age of 71 shortly after the collapse of the communist regime in the [[People's Republic of Poland|People's Republic]], and the re-emergence of sovereign Polish state in the [[Autumn of Nations]].
==Works== Machejek was a political hack writer.<ref name="Paczkowski" /> His most infamous book ''Rano przeszedł huragan'' (''In the Morning There Came A Hurricane'') published in 1955 presented purported crimes in the [[Podhale]] region committed by the ''Ogniowcy'' partisan units under [[Józef Kuraś]].<ref name="tygodnik-onet.pl/2">{{cite web | url=http://tygodnik.onet.pl/1,6945,druk.html | title=Horror podmalowany | publisher=''[[Tygodnik Powszechny]]'' | work=Historia | date=February 27, 2008 | accessdate=August 25, 2012 | author=Maciej Korkuć | quote=Dr Maciej Korkuć jest historykiem, pracuje w krakowskim oddziale IPN: ... ów opis pochodzi z fałszywki – rzekomego pamiętnika „Ognia", w rzeczywistości napisanego ładnych parę lat po jego śmierci.}}</ref> The book was based on a fictional diary of their leader written by Machejek himself. In an often ''coarse'' and even ''primitive'' prose,<ref name="Paczkowski">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=WoKQWem2yl4C&lpg=PA341&ots=pNepaoio_0&dq=%22W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw%20Machejek%22&pg=PA341#v=onepage&q=%22W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw%20Machejek%22&f=false | title=Władysław Machejek (in: Real Socialism: The Iron Fist) | publisher=Penn State Press | work=The Spring Will Be Ours: Poland and the Poles from Occupation to Freedom | year=2003 | accessdate=August 25, 2012 | author=Andrzej Paczkowski, Jane Cave | pages=341– | isbn=0271023082}}</ref> Machejek painted Poland's anti-communists as [[motley crew]] of bloodthirsty anti-Semites who killed Jews, persecuted the Slovak population of the region and who preyed on innocent people.<ref name="tygodnik-onet.pl">{{cite web | url=http://tygodnik2003-2007.onet.pl/0,1355063,druk.html | title=Interview with dr Maciej Korkuć of the Institute of National Remembrance | publisher=''[[Tygodnik Powszechny]]'', reprint by [[Onet.pl]] | work=Partyzant nie nadstawia policzka | year=2007 | accessdate=August 25, 2012 | author=Wojciech Bonowicz and Michał Kuźmiński | quote=''Władysław Machejek spreparował „dziennik" Kurasia. ({{lang-en|how Władysław Machejek invented the Kuraś diary}}).''}}</ref> Although those fragments were simply invented by Machejek, some historians, most recently [[Jan Tomasz Gross]] in his ''[[Fear: Anti-Semitism in Poland After Auschwitz]]'' (2006), have fallen for his claim that the novel was based on facts (Kuraś himself was hunted to death by secret police), thus treating Machejek's falsehood as a valid source.<ref name="tygodnik-onet.pl/2"/>
Polish poet, literary critic and dissident activist [[Stanisław Barańczak]] saw Machejek's style as worthy of mention and wrote an essay, ''U źródeł machejkizmu'', published in his 1990 book ''Książki najgorsze'' (''The Worst of Books''). He suggested that Machejek's style was unique enough to merit a special term, ''machejkizm'' or ''machejcyzm''. According to Barańczak, Machejek's style was a mixture of the worst elements of [[socialist literature|socialist (communist) literature]], namely coarse language of an uneducated man mixed with the pompous and complex [[officialese]] of the Party. Machejek, according to Barańczak, was a master of writing empty sentences, which contain no value, no real message, are not meant to be read, but function simply to fill space.<ref name=Bar>Stanisław Barańczak, ''U źródeł machejkizmu'' [in] ''Książki Najgorsze i parę innych esejów krytycznoliterackich'', Wydawnictwo a5, Poznań 1990, p. 91-94.</ref>
==Bibliography <ref name="inauthor">{{cite web | url=https://www.google.ca/search?hl=en&safe=off&tbo=1&tbm=bks&sclient=psy-ab&q=inauthor%3AW%C5%82adys%C5%82aw+Machejek&btnG= | title=In-author:Władysław Machejek | publisher=Google books | accessdate=August 25, 2012}}</ref>== *''Po wojnie'' (1954) *''Dzwony'' (1955) *''Zginęli W Walce: Sylwetki Bojowników AL i GL'' (1957) *''Niespokojny człowiek'' (1964) *''Z mojego obserwatorium'' (1969) *''W starym młynie'' (1971) *''Zawytka'' (1972) *''Z wojny tej, wojny złej ...'' (1978) *''Rano przeszedł huragan'' (In the Morning There Came A Hurricane, 1985 reprint)
==Notes and references== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox organization |name = Íslenskir Radíóamatörar
Icelandic Radio Amateurs |image = IRA_logo.png |image_border = |size = 50px |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = ÍRA |motto = |formation = August 14, 1946 |extinction = |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |status = |purpose = Advocacy, Education |headquarters = |location = [[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]] |region_served = [[Iceland]] |membership = |language = [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = Jón Þóroddur Jónsson, TF3JA |main_organ = |affiliations = [[International Amateur Radio Union]] |num_staff = |budget = |website = http://www.ira.is/ |remarks = }} The '''Íslenskir Radíóamatörar''', '''ÍRA''', in [[English language|English]], '''Icelandic Radio Amateurs''' is a national [[non-profit organization]] for [[amateur radio]] enthusiasts in [[Iceland]]. Key membership benefits of the IRA include the sponsorship of [[amateur radio operating award]]s and radio [[contesting|contests]], and a [[QSL card|QSL]] bureau for those members who regularly communicate with [[amateur radio operator]]s in other countries. IRA represents the interests of Icelandic amateur radio operators before Icelandic and international telecommunications regulatory authorities. IRA publishes a monthly membership [[magazine]] called ''[[CQ TF]]''.Íslenskir Radíóamatörar (2008). [http://www.ira.is/english/ "About ÍRA"]. Retrieved Aug. 24, 2017. IRA is the national member society representing Iceland in the [[International Amateur Radio Union]].International Amateur Radio Union (2008). [http://www.iaru.org/iaru-soc.html "Member Societies"]. Retrieved Aug. 1, 2008. == See also == *[[International Amateur Radio Union]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Islenskir Radioamatorar}} [[Category:International Amateur Radio Union member societies|Iceland]] [[Category:Organizations based in Iceland]] [[Category:Organizations based in Reykjavík]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1946]] [[Category:1946 establishments in Iceland]] [[Category:Radio in Iceland]] {{Amateur-radio-stub}} {{Iceland-stub}}
